citations.narrative:
The vaccination schedule in the Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) is not being followed. The PVC states that puppies
receive a rabies vaccination at 16 weeks of age and then at 1 year of age. Records indicate that four puppies received
rabies vaccinations not according to this schedule. A female Bichon Frise (Microchip # 3768) and two female Havanese
(Microchip # 0479 and # 3752) received a rabies vaccination on February 21, 2023 and then again on April 1, 2023. An
additional female Havanese (Microchip # 3766) received a rabies vaccination on January 21, 2023 and then again on
April 1, 2023. Failure to administer vaccines in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule can increase the risk of
disease exposure and disease transmission, and cause illness to the animals. Correct by ensuring that the vaccination
schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and all other instruction in the PVC is followed at all times.

Complete medical records are not being maintained for an adult dog. Records indicate an adult female Bichon Frise
(Microchip # 4315) was receiving topical treatments for hair loss. The instructions from the Attending Veterinarian state to
apply the topical treatment twice a day for 7 to 10 days. The treatments are being performed according to the instruction
from the Attending Veterinarian but the medical record did not record all of the treatments administered with dates of
administration as two days of treatments were not recorded. Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere
with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Complete medical
records must be maintained and include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of
administration. Correct by documenting all treatments given and ensure that medical records are complete and contain
the required information.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 28, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
3.13(a)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
The vaccination schedule in the Program of Veterinary Care (PVC) is not being followed. The PVC states that puppies 
receive a rabies vaccination at 16 weeks of age and then at 1 year of age. Records indicate that four puppies received 
rabies vaccinations not according to this schedule. A female Bichon Frise (Microchip # 3768) and two female Havanese 
(Microchip # 0479 and # 3752) received a rabies vaccination on February 21, 2023 and then again on April 1, 2023. An 
additional female Havanese (Microchip # 3766) received a rabies vaccination on January 21, 2023 and then again on 
April 1, 2023. Failure to administer vaccines in accordance with a veterinary approved schedule can increase the risk of 
disease exposure and disease transmission, and cause illness to the animals. Correct by ensuring that the vaccination 
schedule approved by the Attending Veterinarian and all other instruction in the PVC is followed at all times. 
3.13(b)(3) 
   
Veterinary care for dogs. 
Complete medical records are not being maintained for an adult dog. Records indicate an adult female Bichon Frise 
(Microchip # 4315) was receiving topical treatments for hair loss. The instructions from the Attending Veterinarian state to 
apply the topical treatment twice a day for 7 to 10 days. The treatments are being performed according to the instruction 
from the Attending Veterinarian but the medical record did not record all of the treatments administered with dates of 
administration as two days of treatments were not recorded. Failure to maintain adequate medical records may interfere 
with the ability of APHIS officials to determine if the animals are receiving adequate veterinary care. Complete medical 
records must be maintained and include the names of all vaccines and treatments administered and the dates of 
administration. Correct by documenting all treatments given and ensure that medical records are complete and contain 
the required information. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “A” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by January 28, 2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license 
fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.

Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
